Award.AwardTitle: Relative Paleointensity (RPI) and Age Control in Antarctic Marine Drift Sediments
Award.AbstractNarration:
During the last interglacial (LIG) warm interval, ~125 thousand years ago, mean global temperature is estimated to have been only very slightly elevated (by perhaps 1-2 Â°C), relative to today. At that same time, global sea level was elevated by ~6-9 m, relative to present, according to studies of exposed corals in Australia, the Seychelles, and the Caribbean. Such high sea level today would displace up to 20% of the US population. It is estimated that Greenland glacial melting could have accounted for ~2 m of sea-level rise, thermal expansion of the oceans and melting of mountain glaciers could account for ~0.5 m each, but Antarctica must account for the bulk of it. Where did the melting occur? It has been speculated that the one particular part of Antarctica (the West Antarctic Ice Sheet, WAIS) was the site of the inferred melting. The marine sediments that have accumulated off-shore West Antarctica should provide evidence of this melting, but the lack of robust age control in Antarctic marine sediments has stymied their interpretation in terms of past instability of WAIS. This proposal tests a relatively new method, involving the recording of the past geomagnetic field by the sediments themselves, that can provide age models for the Antarctic marine sediments, contribute their interpretation in terms of instability of WAIS over the last few climate cycles, and hence contribute to our current climate/sea level dilemma.

Over the last 20 years, relative (geomagnetic) paleointensity (RPI) proxies have been combined with oxygen isotope data in Quaternary sediments in the North Atlantic with the objective of implementing RPI as a high-resolution stratigraphic correlation tool. The relatively rapid rate of change of geomagnetic field intensity (currently about 5% per century), and the fact that sediments with sedimentation rates <~50 cm/kyr are likely to record only the main axial dipole component of the field, means that RPI can be expected to provide a high-resolution global correlation tool. There are now several examples of tandem correlations involving RPI and oxygen isotope data over the last few Myrs, implemented through automated matching protocols such as 'Match'. The results have led to the generation of temporally calibrated reference stacks for RPI (such as PISO) that can be used, in conjunction with oxygen isotope data, to provide improvements in the resolution of Quaternary stratigraphies. This proposal is to test the use of RPI as a stratigraphic tool in marine sediment drifts off the Antarctic Peninsula and in the Bellingshausen Sea, using seven piston cores recovered in early 2015 during cruise JR298 of the RRS James Clark Ross. The west Antarctic region provides an important test of the stratigraphic role of relative paleointensity (RPI) proxies because the sedimentation history of Antarctic sediment drifts is a key to interpreting their sedimentation history in terms of instability of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet (WAIS) and Antarctic Peninsula Ice Sheet (APIS). The paucity of foraminiferal carbonate at high southerly latitudes means that age models in sediments from the region cannot rely on oxygen isotope data. Age models in these Antarctic drifts have relied on the association of high biogenic siliceous/carbonate percentage (as well as proxies for high biogenic content from magnetic susceptibility, wet bulk density and biogenic Ba content) with interglacial marine isotopic stages. These methodologies are not ideal because they have low resolution and impose interpretations on the sediment record. For these reasons, we seek new methods for determining age in these drift sediment using RPI to interpret sedimentation rates, XRF core scanning data, and ice-rafting debris (IRD) proxies, in terms of instability of WAIS and APIS. This project will be assisted by an undergraduate researcher.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Climate change and global warming are resulting in sea-level rise because of thermal expansion of ocean water but, more importantly, because of melting of ice stored on the continents (mainly in Greenland and Antarctica).  We estimate that during the last interglacial stage about 120.000 years ago (there was an intervening glacial stage between then and now), sea level was ~6-8 m higher than today and global temperatures were a few degrees higher than today. So where was ice melting to result in ~6-8 m sea-level rise during the last interglacial? The best bet is west Antarctica, specifically the West Antarctic Ice Sheet (WAIS) and the Antarctic Peninsula Ice Sheet (APIS). Off the Antarctic Peninsula, there are sediment drifts that accumulated at high sedimentation rates during the last few million years. These sediment drifts undoubtedly contain the signal of past instabiity of the WAIS and APIS ice sheets, during the last interglacial and further back in time. The problem is that it is difficult to date these sediments because the calcium carbonate from tiny organisms (foraminifera) that provide the oxygen isotopic data to determine age throughout most of the world's ocean is almost totally absent off Antarctica.  For this reason, we have developed a means of determining age in sediments that do not contain foraminifera, or contain them in very low abundance. We use the record of intensity of the Earth's magnetic field as recorded by sediments at the time of deposition, referred to as relative paleointensity (RPI). We know the history of intensity of the Earth's magnetic field from studies in other parts of the world's oceans where the RPI record has been calibrated in time. By matching RPI data from off the Antarctic Peninsula to calibrated templates, we can date the sediments off Antarctica and potentially recover the history of instability of WAIS and APIS. Based on study of 10-15 m long sediment cores collected during a scientific cruise to Antarctica in 2015, we came to the following conclusions. The RPI records off Antarctica are affected by oxidation of the mineral (magnetite) that carries the record of RPI in sediments. At some sites, the oxidation process has not progressed and RPI data can be adequately correlated to our calibrated templates. The age models that we have generated from RPI are supported by sparse oxygen isotope data that have been generated from rare foraminifera picked from the sediments. Relative paleointensity (RPI) is a viable tool for determining age of the Antarctic sediments at locations where the oxidation of magnetite has not progressed. The data from the 2015 cruise indicate that the method can be applied over the last few hundred thousand years. A relative paleointensity (RPI) record from Ocean Drilling Project (ODP) Site 1101, published in 1998, can be matched to comtemporary reference RPI templates, indicating that the method can be applied at least back to 1.5 million years before present.
